title: 104_hr1114
content: AUTHORITY FOR 16- AND 17-YEAR-OLDS TO LOAD MATERIALS INTO SCRAP PAPER BALERS AND PAPER BOX COMPACTORS. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to allow 16- and 17-year-old employees to load materials into scrap paper balers and paper box compactors that are safe and cannot be operated while being loaded. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to allow 16- and 17-year-old employees to load scrap paper balers and paper box compactors that meet safety standards set by the American National Standards Institute. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to allow 16- and 17-year-old employees to operate scrap paper balers and paper box compactors certified to be safe for minors by the Secretary. The machines must have key-lock on-off switches controlled by employees aged 18 or older, kept off when not in use, and provided by employers for young employees. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to allow 16- and 17-year-old employees to operate certified safe scrap paper balers and paper box compactors. Employers must provide notice and post a notice stating that young employees can only load the machines, while those under 18 cannot operate or unload them. The Secretary will publish a standard in the Federal Register. The Fair Labor Standards Act now permits 16- and 17-year-old employees to operate certified safe scrap paper balers and paper box compactors. Employers must report any injuries to employees under 18 resulting from contact with the machines during loading, operation, or unloading. The Secretary will publish safety standards in the Federal Register. The reports must include details of any injuries or fatalities of employees under 18 from contact with scrap paper balers or paper box compactors. The Secretary will use these reports to assess the impact of safety measures on children's safety. The reports required by subparagraph (A) must include details of injuries or fatalities of employees under 18 from incidents involving scrap paper balers or paper box compactors. Information such as employer and employee details, incident date, injury description, and equipment model must be provided in the reports. The reports must include details of injuries or fatalities of employees under 18 from incidents involving scrap paper balers or paper box compactors. Information such as employer and employee details, incident date, injury description, and equipment model must be provided in the reports, which should be submitted promptly to the Secretary within 10 days of the incident. The Secretary cannot solely rely on these reports to determine violations of child labor laws and regulations. The Secretary must investigate and inspect reports related to oppressive child labor or regulations issued under section 12 before making a determination. Reporting requirements will expire 2 years after enactment. SEC. 2 amends Section 16(e) of the Fair Labor Standards Act to include section 13(c)(5) and clarifies penalties. SEC. 3 ensures that apprentices and student learners' exemption in section 570.63 of title 29 CFR is not affected.
